docs.abstract: Far more money has gone into attacking the A.C.A. than defending it. Maybe it's not surprising that people neither understand it nor like it.
docs.snippet: Far more money has gone into attacking the A.C.A. than defending it. Maybe it's not surprising that people neither understand it nor like it.

docs.lead_paragraph: About $235 million has gone to advertisements attacking the law, which most Americans want overturned, and $69 million to ads supporting it.

headline.seo: Health Care Law Loses Ad War
headline.main: Distaste for Health Care Law Reflects Spending on Ads
headline.print_headline: Opinion of Health Care Law Reflects Ad Spending

docs.abstract: National polls have consistently found that the Affordable Care Act remains unpopular among voters, even those who would benefit most directly from it; opinion reflects the more than $235 million that has been spent by conservative groups on advertisements attacking the law.
docs.snippet: About $235 million has gone to advertisements attacking the law, which most Americans want overturned, and $69 million to ads supporting it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Over half of all African-Americans and other non-Hispanic blacks in the city who were old enough to work had no jobs this year, according to an analysis of employment data.

headline.seo: Blacks Miss Out as Jobs Rebound in New York City
headline.main: Blacks Miss Out as Jobs Rebound in New York City
headline.print_headline: Blacks Miss Out As Jobs Market Rebounds in City

docs.abstract: Analysis of employment data compiled by the federal Labor Department finds that African-Americans and other non-Hispanic blacks in New York City are faring far worse than residents of other races; more than half of the city's black residents are unemployed and, on average, spend a full year looking for work.
docs.snippet: Over half of all African-Americans and other non-Hispanic blacks in the city who were old enough to work had no jobs this year, according to an analysis of employment data.

byline.contributor: Aaron Edwards and Eric P. Newcomer contributed reporting.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve increased its efforts to revive economic growth by extending its existing asset-purchase program through the end of the year.

headline.main: With Output Stumbling, Fed Takes a Modest Step
headline.print_headline: Output Slower, Fed Is Taking A Modest Step

docs.abstract: Federal Reserve increases its efforts to revive economic growth by extending its existing asset-purchase program through the end of 2012; it will buy $267 billion in long-term Treasury securities; Fed predicts growth of 1.9 percent to 2.4 percent in 2012, inflation will not rise above 1.7 percent, and that unemployment will not fall below 8 percent.
docs.snippet: The Federal Reserve increased its efforts to revive economic growth by extending its existing asset-purchase program through the end of the year.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the economy slowly expanding, state tax revenues have started to recover, but governors and legislatures are keeping a tight rein on spending.

headline.seo: Public Workers Face Continued Layoffs, and Recovery Is Hurt
headline.main: Public Workers Face New Rash of Layoffs, Hurting Recovery
headline.print_headline: Layoffs Hitting Public Workers; Recovery Is Hurt

docs.abstract: Governors and state legislatures are keeping a tight rein on spending, despite the fact that state revenues have started to recover, and as a result, job losses in the public sector have become the single biggest drag on the recovery in many areas; fourteen states plan to resolve their budget gaps by reducing aid to local governments, which will likely exacerbate public sector losses.
docs.snippet: With the economy slowly expanding, state tax revenues have started to recover, but governors and legislatures are keeping a tight rein on spending.

byline.original: By SHAILA DEWAN and MOTOKO RICH

docs.lead_paragraph: A lesbian employee of St. Joseph’s Medical Center claimed that her spouse was entitled to the same medical coverage as the spouses of heterosexual employees.

headline.seo: St. Joseph’s Medical Center Sued Over Benefits by Same-Sex Couple
headline.main: Employee Sues for Benefits to Cover Same-Sex Spouse
headline.print_headline: Employee Sues for Benefits To Cover Same-Sex Spouse

docs.abstract: Lesbian employee of St Joseph’s Medical Center in Westchester County files class-action lawsuit claiming that her spouse is entitled to the same medical coverage as the spouses of heterosexual employees; most companies in New York have extended spousal health benefits to same-sex couples since same-sex marriage became legal, but self-insured employers like St Joseph's are primarily governed by federal, not state, regulations.
docs.snippet: A lesbian employee of St. Joseph’s Medical Center claimed that her spouse was entitled to the same medical coverage as the spouses of heterosexual employees.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama and Mitt Romney have at times been stretching the truth, using statistics without context or just exaggerating.

headline.main: In Romney and Obama Speeches, Selective Truths
headline.print_headline: The Other Rivals: Fact and Interpretation

docs.abstract: Pres Obama and presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney, with the race largely focused on the economy and the budget, are filling speeches with facts and figures designed to enhance their case and diminish their rival's; both candidates are guilty of at times stretching the truth, using statistics without context, exaggerating their own records and misrepresenting their opponent's accomplishments.
docs.snippet: President Obama and Mitt Romney have at times been stretching the truth, using statistics without context or just exaggerating.

byline.original: By PETER BAKER and MICHAEL COOPER
